content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A bit on the harder side conceptually but doable in 5 minutes if you're familiar with it.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and fairly easy to code

‚ùå Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The problem is not articulated well, it is challenging to understand what the overall goal is in a timely manner.

I know an astronomy professor who still uses a calculator like this. I wonder how many people these days are familiar, or if any would recognize the term "postfix" notation. It might be doable in 5 minutes, it was for me. However, you're going to scare people with a link to more documentation during a clash, which no one is going to be able to use anyway. Everything should be contained here, and just bold the term <<reverse Polish notation>> if it's critical to learn.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good clash. It is still one of the harder clashes. Nice aim to the core problem, there's no more corner case.
Solution is straightforward, but it also keeps some time and space for shortest mode.
I think that this is too much for clash of code. I doubt it could be solvable under 5 minutes.

corner case. what if the parameter for acc is not an int?
how to manage 1 2 3 3.2 acc=> Invalid?
The problem is a bit complex; I'm not sure it can be done within the time of a clash, but I'm curious to hear the other comments. 
A suggestion could be to remove error handling (only formally corrected cases) so there's time to focus on reducing the code size (for Shortest game mode)
Good job!

Goal
* Please change "Make a calculator"  to "Write a calculator program".

* Please change "polish" to "Polish" (twice).

* Please change "written with" to "written in".

* Please fix the typo: "requiered" => "required".

* Please fix the typo: "acculate" => ??? (I don't know what you are trying to say).

* Please fix the typo: "operrands" => "operrands".

* Please fix the typo: "evalate" => "evaluate".

* What do you mean by "the last a operands"? "The top a operands in the stack"?

Output
* Please change "decimals" to "decimal places".

* Please fix the typo: "evaluted" => "evaluated".

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement e.g. "write answer".

Cases
* Please fix the typo in the name of a test: "Accumate" ("Accumulate"?).

* Please add a pair of cases where the second decimal place is 0 and should be omitted in output, e.g. 4.70 => 4.7.

* Please add a pair of cases where the output is 0.

Thanks.

Fixed, thanks you.

* What do you mean by "the last a operands"? "The top a operands in the stack"?
Yes it mean what you thought, I replace it by "Accumulate, sum of the next {{a}} values in the stack".

I apologize for the typo, I forgot to fix them before I submitted.

yes I thought about it, and took the easy way (the one you suggested) that's why there is the constraint : "Contains only valid operators and operand values.".
Maybe it need to be a bit more specific, I fixed it thanks you :)
But you made me think, there is another corner case I didn't think about is the case where the parameter for 'acc' is negative and is obvously invalid.

I hesitate between to force the player to manage all thoses edge cases, or not at all for simplicity.
My thought about it is to force the player the manager the two of them, I explain why : 
those two edge cases are relative to incorrect intputs, a common issue in most software developpement (never trust the inputs, even less from the user or a trainee who said "I assure you it works" ^^) and I think it's better to learn to manage those cases than just remove it.
But I may (just a little bit) be influenced by a chronic lack of trust about everything related to inputs :).

I'm curious to know your opinion before making any more changes.
Thanks
Why have you changed your mind? You rejected the contribution before.

It‚Äôs a friend of mine, a kind of guru in the black art of routing electronics design, who is still using (and loving) this type of calculator that made me think of the puzzle.
I'm pretty young compared to him, and I‚Äôve learned a lot thanks to him, so not too far from your professor! :)
I think you‚Äôre right. I removed the wiki link; it can be scary to see it for a 5-minute puzzle. It was originally there for those who wanted to learn more after solving the exercise.
Hmm it does need to be cleaned up a little.

Puzzle was modified. Explanation from creator was under my decline comment, but both disappear.

Now the puzzle does not contains corner cases which in clash of code requires:
a) read all the text carefully
b) run testcases and debug failures
c) and usually put some if-else blocks just for those cases.
All right. That makes sense. Thanks.

Thank you.
I didn't know my comment will be deleted in that case...
to summarize I modified the puzzle as follow :
- all operand are integer (mixed integer/float previously)
- inverse operator changed to  to negate operator in regard of the previous line
- removed an operator with 3 operands to keep only one of each 1, 2 and n operand operators
- removed all corner case for simplicity like divide by zero, stack not empty at the end, invalid operand...
Comments associated with rejection of a contribution are removed when the rejection is withdrawn.

Currently the jump to "Long formula" is quite big. Suggest to add a pair of cases before "Long formula" to cover a shorter formula with all 3 operators out of which 2 are in the middle, such as "-101 -721 -831 3 acc neg 64 add".

Also suggest to renumber the validators.

Thanks.

Done and fixed thank you :)
Added two test cases :
- A test case for testing "negate" only
- A test case with the three operations as suggested

Renamed validators and the shorter cases including their corresponding "classic" formula for helping.

I suggested removing the Invalid cases to focus on a reduced implementation with the Shortest objective. 
Handling incorrect input is certainly an important experience, as you describe, but I see it as incompatible with the shortest objective. 
I believe 15 minutes is too little time to do a good job.
But I‚Äôm a bit old and definitely rusty.
Let's see what others say; I'll return to the puzzle a few days before the deadline to approve. Thanks!

Another option for the accumulate operation (which to be honest is new to me) would have been to sum everything on the stack, i.e. take no operand for the count. I'm not sure if that's easier to implement, but it feels that way.

No worries üôÇ

There's still a typo of "acumulate" in Goal section. You may change it to "accumulate", and "store" is another word you may consider.

Thanks.

Fixed.
And thanks for "store", it fits better :)
